Award.AwardTitle: Developing reduced basis methods for Galerkin and Collocation framework
Award.AbstractNarration:
Reduced basis method (RBM) is a model reduction framework for rapid and reliable simulations of input-parametrized partial differential equations. Many applications require simulations to be repeated tens of thousands of times to study the effect of the parameters on the solution. This repetition can be prohibitive in terms of computational cost. The RBM can provide a surrogate solution in negligible computational time. A similar approach, known as the reduced basis element method (RBEM) can be employed for computing the surrogate solution on a complicated domain. This method is a combination of domain decomposition and RBM. In this grant proposal, the PI proposes to continue his work in these two areas to design a completely new RBM for the collocation framework and to develop (Galerkin) variants of RBM and RBEM suitable for applications to simulations of scattering problems with large number, wide range of parameters, and rough geometries. The proposed research includes two phases. The first phase aims to build a solid theoretical foundation that includes study of the new collocation-based RBM, a novel error estimation procedure for RBEM, a RBM algorithm design based on efficient error estimation for a wider range of weak formulations. The second phase of this project is the application of the newly-developed methodologies to acoustic/electromagnetic scattering with rather high-dimensional parameter and uncertainties in the geometry of the scatterer. The intellectual merit of the proposed research lies in their comprehensive coverage of novel algorithm design, solid analysis, and efficient implementation.

The PI's work has far-reaching goals beyond the current proposal because of the methods' broad applicability to problems of significant impact in science and engineering. The real-world application areas include (but are not limited to) national security (fine-tuning of the shape and material for stealth technology), renewable energy (design of solar cells), and non-destructive sensing. The broader impact of this proposal will result from its scientific impact and educational component. The results will be widely disseminated and the codes made publicly available. The proposed research will incorporate rigorous undergraduate and graduate student training and mentoring. Special attention will be paid to under-represented groups including minorities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award is for developing a mathematically rigorous and practically efficient algorithm, called reduced basis method, to simulate a multi-parametric system whose parameters (material properties, geometrical configurations, initial and surrounding conditions etc.) need to be tuned thus necessitating prohibitively expensive computer simulations.

Leading his students and colleagues, the principal investigator (PI) successfully achieved all the goals stated in the initial proposal. First, they widened the applicability of the reduced basis method by extending it to a different but practically important framework in a consistent and stable manner. Second, they developed an object-oriented package bearing a simple interface for researchers and practitioners in the field to call and obtain a critical component of the reduced basis method to justify the accuracy of the numerical scheme. They included in the new package one of their own discoveries geared toward this particular purpose. Third, the PI also paid close attention to applications of the mathematical algorithms. He designed a new approximate matrix decomposition technique inspired by the reduced basis method. This decomposition is more efficient than the classical algorithms and has been applied to data compression and image processing. The well-documented Matlab package is released. Lastly, the PI's team ventured into the field of uncertainty quantification that was new to them. Hybridizing the reduced basis method with the state-of-the-art uncertainty quantification approach, they have designed and analyzed a new algorithm that is much more efficient than the classical approach that is widely used in the UQ community. Most importantly, this approach has shown promise of delaying the curse of dimensionality since its efficiency improves as the dimension of the randomness increases.

A critical focus of this grant is to nurture the next generation workforce. Toward that end, it has directly helped the training of four undergraduate students and two graduate students in the field of computational science. They were all outstanding young individuals who were pursuing a mathematics degree and would be entering the next generation workforce. The research experience made possible by this grant turned out to be vital for their professional development.

Among the undergraduate students, one has received a prestigious award for doctoral study whose stellar work on this grant was featured on the undergraduate research publications at our school. Two are poised to enter graduate school in 2017 focusing on areas that are particularly inspired by their work on the project. And the last one, equipped with coding skills sharpened through working with the PI, has started a full time job in industry. Their experience working on this project directly contributed to their success. The two graduate students are current, but on track to graduate from our young and interdisciplinary doctoral program at UMass Dartmouth. This grant directly contributed to the nurturing of two computational scientists of the next generation with terminal degree, and to the growth of a quite unique interdisciplinary PhD program. It is noteworthy that the female student secured a competitive internship position in summer 2016 at Sandia national lab. The experience she gained and the expertise she accumulated through involving in this grant is one key factor for her success in obtaining the position and thriving at the lab.
